questions.question:
Question 1: A 45-year-old man was brought to the ER by his friends after they found him lying 
unconscious next to an empty antifreeze bottle. Investigations were significant for the 
following findings. This condition predominantly affects which part of the kidney?
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of acute tubular necrosis (ATN) due to ingestion of ethylene 
glycol. Toxins usually result in ATN by causing damage to the proximal convoluted tubules 
(PCTs). Ethylene glycol poisoning produces marked ballooning and hydropic or vacuolar degeneration of 
PCT. Calcium oxalate crystals are often also found in tubular lumens. Direct toxic injury to the tubules in ATI can be caused by: • Endogenous agents: Myoglobin, hemoglobin, monoclonal light chains, bile/bilirubin • Exogenous agents: Drugs, radiocontrast dyes, heavy metals, and organic solvents

questions.question:
Question 2: A 27-year-old woman presents with urinary frequency, urgency, and burning during urination 
of two days duration. Presence of which of the following additional findings would make you 
suspect pyelonephritis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
White blood cell casts are specific features of pyelonephritis. Neutrophil-rich casts (pus 
casts) indicate renal involvement because casts are formed only in tubules. The urine contains many leukocytes (pyuria) derived from the inflammatory infiltrate. It is found 
in both upper and lower UTIs and cannot differentiate between them. Fever is also a non-specific 
finding. Ascending infection is the most common cause of clinical pyelonephritis. Note: Sterile pyuria is defined as white cells in the urine in the absence of significant bacterial 
growth. It is seen in renal TB.

questions.question: Question 3: What is the most common organism causing acute pyelonephritis?
questions.explanation:
The most common organism causing acute pyelonephritis is Escherichia coli. The organisms that cause acute pyelonephritis include: • E. coli • Proteus • Klebsiella • Enterobacter species • Mycobacteria - caseating granulomatous inflammation • Fungi - non-caseating granulomatous inflammation • Viruses (CMV and adenovirus) - immunocompromised people 808 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 4: Periglomerular fibrosis is considered typical of which of the following conditions? 801 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Periglomerular fibrosis is considered typical of chronic pyelonephritis. Histopathological features of chronic pyelonephritis are: • Dilated tubules with flattened epithelium may be filled with casts resembling thyroid 
colloid (thyroidization) • Chronic interstitial inflammation and fibrosis in the cortex and medulla • Periglomerular fibrosis • Secondary focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), usually several years after the scarring has 
occurred and often in the absence of continued infection or persistent vesicoureteral reflux

questions.question:
Question 5: A pathologist noted the following microscopic finding while examining a slide of a kidney. 
What is the likely cause?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows dilated tubules with flattened epithelium, filled with casts, resembling 
thyroid colloid (thyroidization). This is seen in chronic pyelonephritis. 809 
Sold by @itachibot Option A: In acute tubular necrosis, there is focal tubular epithelial necrosis, tubulorrhexis. Option C: In acute interstitial nephritis, there is patchy edema and mononuclear cell infiltrates. Option D: In systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), wire-loop lesions are seen.

questions.question: Question 6: All of the following patients are at risk of developing renal papillary necrosis except:

options.a: A 14-year-old girl being treated for thalassemia major
options.b: A 60-year-old man with longstanding diabetes mellitus
options.c: A 46-year-old man with a history of analgesic abuse
options.d: A 24-year-old woman identified to have sickle cell trait

questions.explanation: Necrotizing papillitis or acute papillary necrosis is not associated with thalassemia. Major causes of acute papillary necrosis include • Diabetes mellitus • Sickle cell disease or trait • Analgesic abuse nephropathy • Obstruction by calculi • Focally in renal tuberculosis

questions.question:
Question 7: A 48-year-old woman presented with recurrent episodes of flank pain and fever with chills. 
CECT abdomen showed dilated and enlarged left renal pelvis with the multiloculated calyces 
and resection of the kidney was done. The gross specimen showed large yellowish-orange 
nodules. Histological examination revealed foamy macrophages. Which of the following is 
associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
The clinical features and histological findings are suggestive of xanthogranulomatous 
pyelonephritis. It is associated with Proteus infection and obstructive uropathy. Xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis is a relatively rare form of chronic pyelonephritis 
characterized by the accumulation of foamy macrophages intermingled with plasma cells, 
lymphocytes, polymorphonuclear leukocytes, and occasional giant cells. The lesions sometimes produce large, yellowish-orange nodules that may be grossly confused with 
renal cell carcinoma. CECT abdomen shows dilated and enlarged renal pelvis and calyces showing 
a multiloculated appearance referred to as the bear paw sign. 810 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following do not result in granular contracted kidneys?
questions.explanation:
Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis and amyloidosis cause enlarged kidneys. Causes of contracted kidneys: • Symmetric • Chronic glomerulonephritis • Benign nephrosclerosis • Asymmetric • Chronic pyelonephritis Causes of enlarged kidneys: 811 
Sold by @itachibot • Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis • Amyloidosis • Polycystic kidney disease • Hydronephrosis (bilateral obstruction) The following image shows the gross appearance in benign nephrosclerosis illustrating the fine, 
leathery granularity of the surface.

questions.question:
Question 9: Which of the following findings is not associated with malignant hypertension? 803 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Image 4 shows a leather-grain appearance, which is seen in benign nephrosclerosis. Features of malignant hypertension: • Flea bitten kidney - small petechial hemorrhages on the cortical surface, leading to a mottled 
appearance • Fibrinoid necrosis of arterioles - cytologic detail is lost and the vessel wall takes on a smudgy 
eosinophilic appearance due to fibrin deposition • Onion-skinning (hyperplastic arterioles) - intimal thickening with the fine concentric layering of 
collagen & smooth muscles 812 
Sold by @itachibot Onionskinning appearance Fibrinoid riecrosis 813 
Sold by @itachibot The differential diagnosis for flea-bitten kidney includes: • Polyarteritis nodosa • Subacute bacterial endocarditis (SABE) • Malignant hypertension

questions.question: Question 10: Atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome can be caused by all except:
questions.explanation:
Deficiency of ADAMTS13 leads to thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). Two common pathogenetic triggers of thrombotic microangiopathies are: • Endothelial injury - HUS • Excessive platelet activation and aggregation - TTP Typical HUS 
Atypical HUS Mutation in genes encoding c

questions.question:
Question 11: An 8-year-old boy is brought with blood in the urine. His mother says he had bloody diarrhea, 
fever, and vomiting 10 days ago. His BP is 130/•0 mm Hg, and he is jaundiced. Investigations 
reveal a platelet count of 50,000 cells/cu mm, BUN of 35mg/dl, and creatinine of 3.5mg/dl. 
Which of the following cells would you expect to see in the peripheral smear?
questions.explanation:
814 
Sold by @itachibot The clinical scenario is suggestive of hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS). It is characterized by the 
presence of schistocytes in peripheral smear. It indicates microangiopathic hemolytic anemia.

questions.question: Question 12: Cholemic nephrosis is associated with which of the following casts?
questions.explanation:
Cholemic nephrosis is associated with casts of bile. In patients with acute or chronic liver disease with advanced liver failure, renal function may be 
impaired. This is called hepatorenal syndrome. This can be associated with highly elevated 
bilirubin levels with bile cast formation (also known as cholemic nephrosis) in distal nephron 
segments.

questions.question:
Question 13: 804 
Sold by @itachibot A 35-year-old man died in a road traffic accident. On autopsy, the following appearance of the 
kidney was noted. Which of the following is not associated with this condition?

options.a: Cysts in liver, pancreas, and spleen

questions.explanation:
The gross image suggests that the patient had autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney disease 
(ADPKD). This condition is not associated with hepatic fibrosis. However, patients with autosomal 
recessive (childhood) polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) have congenital hepatic fibrosis. ADPKD is associated with mutations in PKD1, encoding polycystin 1, and PKD2, encoding 
polycystin 2. The multiple expanding cysts of both kidneys ultimately destroy the renal 
parenchyma and cause renal failure. Cysts arise from the tubules throughout the nephron and, 
therefore, have variable lining epithelia. The common extrarenal manifestations of ADPKD include: • Hepatic cysts - most common • Seminal vesicle cysts - can result in infertility • Arachnoid membrane cysts - usually asymptomatic, may increase the risk of subdural hematoma • Pancreatic cysts • Splenic cysts • Intracranial berry aneurysms • Subarachnoid hemorrhages • Mitral valve prolapse There are very few case reports with lung cysts in ADPKD patients, but the association between 
ADPKD and lung cysts has not been proved. However, there is a three-fold increase in the 
incidence of bronchiectasis in ADPKD patients.

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following is false about the polycystin gene?

options.a: Polycystin-1 is most commonly involved in ADPKD
options.b: Polycystin-2 is a calcium ion channel
options.c: Mutation in polycystin-2 causes more severe form of ADPKD
options.d: Polycystin-1 is involved in cell interactions

questions.explanation:
The polycystin-2 mutation is less commonly involved and less severe. 815 
Sold by @itachibot Polycystin-1 is encoded by the PKD1 gene located on chromosome 16p13.3. It is expressed in 
tubular epithelial cells, particularly those of the distal nephron. It contains domains that are 
usually involved in cell-cell and cell-matrix interactions. Mutations in PKD1 account for about 
85% of cases of ADPKD (autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease) and it causes a more 
severe form of the disease. Polycystin-2 is an integral membrane protein that is expressed in all segments of the renal tubules 
and in many extrarenal tissues. It functions as a Ca2+ cation channel. Overall, it causes a less 
severe form of ADPKD disease.

questions.question:
Question 15: What is the most common extrarenal site of cysts in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney 
disease?
questions.explanation:
The most common extrarenal site of cysts in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease 
(ADPKD) is the liver. 40% of individuals with autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) have one to 
several cysts in the liver (polycystic liver disease) that are usually asymptomatic. The cysts are 
derived from the biliary epithelium. Cysts occur much less frequently in the spleen, pancreas, and lungs. There are very few case 
reports with lung cysts in ADPKD patients, but the association between ADPKD and lung cysts 
has not been proved.

questions.question: Question 16: In patients with ADPKD, the mutated genes are located on which chromosomes?
questions.explanation:
The genes mutated in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) are located on 
chromosomes 16 and 4. This condition occurs due to mutations of the PKD1 gene (chromosome 16) and PKD2 gene (on 
chromosome 4). These genes encode for polycystin 1 and 2 proteins respectively.

questions.question: Question 17: Mutations in fibrocystin are seen in which condition?
questions.explanation:
Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) is caused by mutations in the PKHD1 
gene on chromosome 6p21-p23 which encodes fibrocystin. The gene is highly expressed in adult and fetal kidneys and also in the liver and 
pancreas. Fibrocystin has been localized to the primary cilium of tubular cells. The serious manifestations of ARPKD are usually present at birth, and may cause death by renal 
failure. The following gross findings are seen: • Enlarged kidneys with smooth external appearance • Spongelike appearance due to numerous small cysts in the cortex and medulla • Dilated elongated channels at right angles to the cortical surface, completely replacing the 
medulla and cortex 816 
Sold by @itachibot On microscopic examination, there is cylindrical or, less commonly, saccular dilation of all 
collecting tubules with linning of cuboidal cells. In almost all cases, the liver has cysts associated 
with portal fibrosis and proliferation of the portal bile ducts, termed congenital hepatic fibrosis.

questions.question: Question 18: Hepatic fibrosis is a feature of which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation: Hepatic fibrosis is a feature of childhood (autosomal recessive) polycystic kidney disease.

questions.question:
Question 19: A routine urine examination of a 46-year-old woman shows thorn-apple crystals. Past history 
is significant for constipation and longstanding use of laxatives. What is the likely 
composition of these crystals?
questions.explanation:
Ammonium biurate crystals appear as spheres with radial or concentric striations and irregular 
projections or thorns, referred to as thorn apples. They are seen in laxative abuse.

questions.question: Question 20: In patients with chronic kidney disease, what type of casts are seen?

options.a: It is inherited as an autosomal recessive disorder
options.b: It is associated with MIC-2 gene expression
options.c: It is associated with the deletion of chromosome 11p13
options.d: The most common presentation is hematuria

questions.explanation:
Broad casts are seen in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD). They are also known as renal 
failure casts. Broad casts are defined as those with a diameter 2-6 times that of normal casts. They indicate 
chronically damaged tubules or collecting ducts. They indicate a poor prognosis. 817 
Sold by @itachibot Renal Tumors
